p.s: William Shakespeare is very famous for his construction of plots and characters in his plays and that great way of storytelling is also visible in this scene due to his description of the relationship between Macbeth and his wife.

The effects would be not as effective without Shakespeare's use of stylistic devices and diverse metaphors to create word-scenery for the audience to illustrate the setting and scenery which cannot be build up on stage.
This scene depicts the specialties of the relationship between Macbeth and his wife during a crucial point of their life.
Lady Macbeth reveals that she is very decisive and would like to convince her husband to commit a crime and kill his king.
But at first, Macbeth clearly shows his position and states: We will proceed no further in this business (l. 4).
This paratactical, clear sentence even includes the personal pronoun we which is used by Macbeth to state his authority and hinder his wife intriguatingintriguing further.

Macbeth also explains his position with the usage of metaphors like Golden opinions (l. 6) and newest gloss (l. 7) which illustrate that he already has to face a prosperous future even if he would not use this chance.

But instead of accepting his decision, Lady Macbeth answers in an allegory about a drunken hope (cf. l. 9) which wakes up green and pale (l. 11) which is a reference on the withe'switches' prophecy and Macbeth's displeasure to helo proceeding the kingship.

Lady Macbeth asks fastly many direct questions and furthermore describes her man in a comparison as afeared to be the same (...) as thou art in desire? (ll. 13-15) which demonstrates that she would like to taunt him as much that he is urgent to handle.
She is also using metaphors like the ornament of life (l. 16) to express the effects on him, if he reaches his prophecy goal.
That is how she would like to exaggerate the benefits of becoming king, so that it is like a viscerousviscous appeal for his greed which only must be accepted by Macbeth.

This opportunity which is opened up by the king'sKing's visit at their castle should be used and that is why Lady Macbeth compares Macbeth's decision in a metaphor with a cat sitting in front of a pond which would like to eat fish but not to become wet (cf. l. 19).
That is how she remembers Macbeth that the prophecy could also not become true if he is not urgent and does not use illegal practices.

Due to the remembering on his greed and the taunt about his manliness, Macbeth states offended that he does everything to be a man (cf. l. 21) and exaggerates his ambition to be a man in the sentence: Who dares do more is none (l. 22).

But on the other hand to this reaction full of decisiveness and proudness he also asks his wife to become silent (cf. l. 20) and speaks all in all much less than his wife which reveals that he is the inferior partner in this situation.

His wife has reacted on his decision with a lot of accusational questions in a lengthy contribution and taunts her man because she knows that this action will activate his consciousness for proudness and manliness, so that he will decide to kill Duncan.
In addition to that, she also goes on after the short interruption by Macbeth and continues asking him questions about his motivation.
Exemplarily, she asks him what beast (l. 23) has hindered him to proceed killing Duncan.

In this case the word beast shows her choice of a dramatic, cruel language to exaggerate how much power must have been needed to persuade such a strong man, as Macbeth describes himself, to neglect this opportunity.
Lady Macbeth also makes a condition, when Macbeth is a real man (cf. l. 25) to force him to agree on her plan because he would be no man, if he would not compete in her opinion.
In the next part of her lengthy contribution, Lady Macbeth depicts that she would even treat her own child cruel, if it would allow her to fullfilfulfil her goald (cf. ll. 30-35).
That is how she builds up a contrast between her unscrupulousness and his doubting.
That contrast is even tensified when Macbeth answers and asks: If we should fail? (l. 36) in a very short paratactical sentence which reveals his insecureness, doubts and the feeling of inferiority.
Lady Macbeth reacts even shorter with the harsh ellipsis: We fail! (l. 37) to neglect any resistance against her position and show her ambition to not fail.
Instead, she would give the fault for a failure his man (cf. l. 38f.) and that is how she would like to convince him to act decisively to not cause a failure.

Furthermore, she describes in detail how easy her plan will be and examines that Duncan will easily fall to sleep with a paranthesis (cf. ll. 39-41) to give Macbeth a feeling of security and a plannable action.

She explains that she will make the chamberlains drunk with the alliteration wine and wassail (l. 42) and arranges the emphasis for the drunkness arroundaround the metaphor of the memory, the warder of brain (l. 43) that is also why she exaggerates the guard's unconsciousness with more words reacting to the alcoholic word-field, like fume (l. 44) or limbeck (l. 45), and with a comparison of their sleep as in death (l. 47).
After that, she uses two rhetorical questions arranged as parallelisms and anaphoras (cf. ll. 47-50) to express and exaggerate what they could achieve by using this opportunity.
To this plan Macbeth reacts with his wish that Lady Macbeth will only give birth to male children due to her decisiveness (cf. ll. 51-53).
This wish underlines that Macbeth feels himself overhelmedoverwhelmed by the arguments of his wife and her dirty strategies.
Nevertheless, he is convinced and now follows his wife's plan, so that he understands that he needs to hide their ambition and expresses that understanding in a sentence with two metaphors (l. 58).
All in all, it seems to be very clear that Lady Macbeth is superior in this scene.
She taunts her husband and makes him believe in the good conditions of this opportunity.
She appeals to his greed and reaches her goals which shows how shemerschemer and intriguantintriguer this person is also in her relationship with Macbeth.
